 I disagree with you on only one thing and that would be the difficulty of the shot. It was, according to the evidence I have seen a straight on shot. That is to say the vehicle was moving quite slowly and in a straight line. Oswald would have had only to move his rifle up or down but not sideways to get off the additional shots. I would think the chances of getting off a clean shot would have been greatly enhanced.
 
 Having said that, I don't own one of these relics. I understand that Oswald paid about $12 for it via the post office. I do own a 22 rifle and although I'm no great shot, with a scope I can get some pretty accurate shots off. It doesn't of course have the whallop of a large caliber bullet but a $100 Marlin semi-automatic one could get off about 15 shots in that allotted time and those head shots would definitely have been fatal. On the other hand, when I owned a 9mm Beretta handgun, I couldn't hit the broad side of a barn. My Ruger 22 handgun however is amazingly accurate for a lousy shooter like me, however. I just thought I would throw this into the mix for whatever it is worth.

 On the Lincoln assassination I thought all of the perpetrators were found and duly hung. I had thought the controversey arose as to whether or not John Wilkes Booth actually died in that barn fire. About a year ago I happened to hear the reading of an author at the Civil War museum in Corsicana, Texas where the writer claimed to have talked to Booth long after the fact. These things are never really settled even when the assassin remains alive, just like the MLK and Robert Kennedy murders. Some writer is out to make a quick buck. And there will always be the gullible. These writers take a few selected known facts and then weave them with theories and suppositions to make a believable story. I'm reminded of the part in "Little Big Man" where the con man Martin Balsam is relating to Dustin Hoffman how he could concoct most any theory and make it believable. And those were completely bizarre but some believed. When I hear these things I usually just smile and walk away.
